Column Comment.0: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.1: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.2: AMERICAN PETROLEUM INTSTITUTE GRAVITY MAXIMUM: The maximum valuefor the gravity of this substance as per the American Petroleum Institute and theNational Institute of Standards and Technology.
Column Comment.3: AMERICAN PETROLEUM INTSTITUTE GRAVITY MINIMUM: The minimum valuefor the gravity of this substance as per the American Petroleum Institute and theNational Institute of Standards and Technology.
Column Comment.4: ATOMIC MASS: The atomic mass of the element in this row.
Column Comment.5: ATOMIC MASS NUMBER: The atomic mass number of the element in this row.
Column Comment.6: ATOMIC WEIGHT: The atomic weight of the element or composite in this row.
Column Comment.7: CARBON COUNT: For a hydrocarbon that has a single allowable carbon count. Forexample, Methane has 1 carbon atom, and Ethane has 2 carbon atoms.
Column Comment.8: CARBON COUNT MAXIMUM: For a hydrocarbon family that includes a range ofcarbon counts, the maximum carbon count included in this substance. For example,aromatic hydrocarbons may be generally defined as having between 6 and 8 carbonatoms in an appropriate configuration.
Column Comment.9: CARBON COUNT MINIMUM: For a hydrocarbon family that includes a range ofcarbon counts, the minimum carbon count included in this substance. For example,aromatic hydrocarbons may be generally defined as having between 6 and 8 carbonatoms in an appropriate configuration.
Column Comment.10: COMPOSITION FORMULA: The chemical formula of the composition in this row. Forexample the chemical formula for isobutane is (CH3)3CH.
Column Comment.11: CONVERSION QUANTITY: A Conversion code for a generic set of conversionfactors (GAS VOL and OIL VOL) CONVERSION QUANTITY: The generic fluid orQuantity to be used when looking up applicable conversion factors in thePPDM_VOL_MEAS_CONV table.
Column Comment.12: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.13: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.14: IONIC CHARGE: The ionic charge of the element or composition in this row. Specifyif cation or anion by using + or -, respectively.
Column Comment.15: Molecular mass: The molecular mass of the molecule in this row.
Column Comment.16: MASS OVER CHARGE ION: the mass of a molecular fragment (in atomic mass unitsor grams per mole) divided by the charge of the molecular fragment (largely a -1charge). As compound elute from the end of a gas chromatography column in aGCMS they are bombardedby an electron beam with an ionization energy of 70 eV.This amount of energy is just enough to break each compound into distinct molecularfragments that largely have a -1 charge - giving the tool the specificity to uniquelyidentify compounds. These m/z molecules are further separated by the magnetic fieldprior to smashing into the mass spectrometer detector. In comparison, an ICP-MS orinductively coupled plasma mass spec using a very very high ionization energy at5000 degrees C which totally atomizes all compounds and results in an elementalcomposition - commonly used for water analysis - e.g. sulfate or SO4-- is brokendown to pure S.
Column Comment.17: PHASE TYPE: The type of phase the substance in the row is; gas, liquid or solid.Pending on changes in the environment physical phase changes may occur to thesubstance.
Column Comment.18: PH VALUE: The pH value of the substance in this row.
Column Comment.19: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.20: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this substance ispreferred.
Column Comment.21: PREFERRED LONG NAME: the usual or preferred name given to this substance.Denormalise this for performance reasons from SUBSTANCE ALIAS if you use thiscolumn (the value should be in both tables).
Column Comment.22: PREFERRED SHORT NAME: Common short name used for the production entity.The usual or preferred short name given to this substance. Denormalise this forperformance reasons from SUBSTANCE ALIAS if you use this column (the valueshould be in both tables).
Column Comment.23: PREFERRED UNIT OF MEASURE: The unit of measure in which volumes for thissubstance should be usually be stored by preference. This may be modified in detailtables SUBSTANCE TABLE or SUBSTANCE COLUMN for specific use in individualtables and columns. It is usually most effecient if a particular substance is alwaysstored in the same units, but sometimes business needs dictate that some values bein different units of measure.
Column Comment.24: TABLE PROPERTY CONTROL SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the propertycontrol information. This can be used to help you control how a vertical table isimplemented, by determining preferred units of measure, data entry types and otherspecifications for each kind of property that is defined.
Column Comment.25: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data
Column Comment.26: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.27: SOURCE DOCUMENT: The literature reference for the information about thesubstance in this row.
Column Comment.28: SUBSTANCE DEFINITION: The full, narrative definition for a substance should beprovided here. For substances used in scientific literature, this may be used inconjunction with the bibliographic reference in SOURCE DOCUMENT. If a substancehasmore than one definition, each definition should likely be related to its ownSUBSTANCE ID. This may occur, particularly for terms (such as OIL) which are usedby many sources with different definitions.
Column Comment.29: VALENCE VALUE: The value of the valence electrons for the substance in this row.
Column Comment.30: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.31: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.ho lastchanged the row.
Column Comment.32: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.33: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.34: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.35: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.36: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
